comments.commentBody: One of the most important findings of "Crisis in the Kindergarten," the report that Joan Almon and I wrote for the Alliance for Childhood in 2009 and is cited in this op-ed piece, is that what many classroom teachers and school administrators call "play" is not in fact playful at all. That's why I object to Polakow-Suransky's and Nager's use of the terms "purposeful play" and "meaningful play." I have been in many early childhood classrooms where the teachers proudly point to the children's "purposeful play"--but what is actually going on is carefully controlled and scripted by the teacher, and the "choices" that children are allowed are pitifully narrow and joyless. Let children be children! Let their play be play--even when adults see no particular purpose to it!

Ellsberg disclosed classified information to end an unjust war.  Snowden disclosed classified information to disclose the fact that the government is collecting too much classified information.  You can support one or both of them.  But, in my opinion, the different motives make these very different cases, not "essentially the same thing."

To deal with political assassins like McConnell and Boehner, you need to have the ferocity of LBJ or Ben Bradlee but sadly, Obama disdains that kind of trench warfare!
Bradlee was a wonderful man and amazing editor - but how can President Obama laud him for publishing the Pentagon Papers and then pursue Snowden for doing essentially the same thing?

This same concept needs to be expanded to older students for whom intellectual exploration has been replaced by standardized testing as the touchstone of our educational system. We aren't educating if the system is based on standardized tests rather than engagement between student and teacher and student and subject matter.

When my children were small I came upon the Gesell
Books that guide parents through the stages of childhood.
I found the books terrific. What I have not forgotten is
The theory that play is how children really learn.

As a Bank Street graduate myself, I can tell you assuredly that the authors of this article, and the practitioners of this approach, ALWAYS read to pre-schoolers every day.  This article, as great as it is, does omit that information.  The authors are focusing here on the very important play aspect of early childhood education, but in the classes described here there is always a "meeting" time or circle time when the members of the class are gathered in a group to hear a story and to discuss it and many other aspects of their day and their lives.

HOw fortunate that your children were born into a family where there is time, space, and educated parents.   Many children have only a TV on all the time.   And it isn't tuned to movies of great works.

What about reading great books aloud to children?

Once upon a time, children's days would be filled with nursery rhymes, fairy tales and fables. Much wisdom and learning was transferred this way.

I have a four-year-old (currently asleep) who is just spellbound by great books. His block and lego play as well as his lunchtime chit-chat with his brother are inspired by books, books and more books.

Freedom to play with toys is wonderful, but a child's imagination without a live human voice reading great books is like a sailboat without wind.

With books... that sailboat... well, you will just have to read chapter VII of E.B. White's classic "Stuart Little" to catch my drift.

Please make reading great books to children a deep and meaningful part of preK in NYC.
As the parent of a four year old this is almost completely banal, and mostly useless.  It would be nice to have something concrete

There is no evidence that unrestricted play increases academic performance. These young poor children lack background knowledge and vocabulary. They can not learn these things from playing with their friends. It is up to a knowledgeable teacher to instruct their children. It is the teacher's responsibly to devise ACTIVITIES that will lead to an increase in academic knowledge. Eighty-one excellent lessons are available free on the Core Knowledge Foundation's web site: www.coreknowledge.com/lessons. They also have an excellent PreK CD available for only $19.95.
No PreK program can lead to long term academic gains without the support of the parents. PreK programs must have a very extensive parent information and training component. It might be a good idea to develop a DVD that shows parents how to how to encourage their children to love knowledge. Parents don't have to become teachers; their role is to let their children how important education is to them and that they expect their children to work hard and do very well. Just passing or just graduating should not be unacceptable.

I think Kate has it almost exactly wrong when she says: "We need to get into the mechanics of play and actually drive it somehow and push our children like technology pushes adults to new levels of understanding the world."  What we need is to free young children (and everyone) from such pressures and allow our own humanity to rise to the fore.  The constant pressure to 'perform,' even when such performance is close to meaningless, robs us of the humanizing play experiences the article's authors write about.

Wow! I'm the first to write a comment...OK.  I'm not buying this theory.  My experience with "Academic Studies in Education" is that they never delve into the materials or the actual mechanics of what's being explored.   I signed up years ago for education credits at my local college thinking I would like to go into this area and to my surprise we never really observed students or the process we just talked on such a high level and I was left with the impression that getting down and dirty with the actual tasks being undertaken by the children was just too low to go.   This idea of "grit" is just a very fluffy theory.  We need to get into the mechanics of play and actually drive it somehow and push our children like technology pushes adults to new levels of understanding the world.
Why does play time have to be supervised by the government to be effective?

The authors are quite right- for early childhood, play is the thing. Interestingly, in both the wealthy and the poorer ends of the social strata play is missing not only in school, but in daily life. The richer parents have fallen victim to overscheduling their kids' every moment, and the poorer parents must leave their kids in the care of others for many hours on end, people who might not appreciate the value say of a bunch of 5 yr olds exploring puddles together. I taught preschool for years, and the kids taught me early on that everything of necessity could be learned through play. Its true, play has sometimes to be 'guided', as in making sure the girls get time with the blocks, and boys with the dress up, but that's really a matter of tuning, which the teacher can do by paying attention. "Plays well with others' is of great value through life, not the least of which is in intimate relationships.

Piaget's research and its emphasis on active, child directed learning is well known to early childhood professionals and has been informing preschool curricula for years. For example the High Scope program was developed I. The early days of Head Start and has show important long term effects. Sadly our society is so obsessed with demonstrating learning on paper that we ignore what we have learned from developmental psychology.

http://www.highscope.org/Content.asp?ContentId=181

The Swiss psychologist Jean Piaget devoted his life and extraordinary career to research of the development children's intelligence — a field he pioneered and called 'genetic epistemology.'

People in all professions and walks of life, but particularly those in early education would get wonderful benefits from reading his work. As an architect, I was inspired and used his methodology and concepts in professional education and directing post-graduate for architects — of incalculable value was "The Child's Conception of Space."

There are landmarks in pedagogical theory and practice that require continuous revisit and pilgrimage to — Piaget's work is definitely one not to be missed.

http://webspace.ship.edu/cgboer/Piaget.html
Why do third graders need to be tested by the state?

The good old days, when kindergarten was preschool. When we did not send our kids to work at 7 AM to 5 PM. at age 4. When homework was held off until high school. High school was a place to prepare for a job, not another 5 years of school and $100,000 in debt.
Some Russian writer nailed it 100 years ago when expounded on the American Scholl System.
Preschool ain't for the kids is it really Mr. and Mrs. Hovercrafts. it is all about you.

Purposeful play as a form of education, particularly in a pre-school setting, is a great introduction to classroom learning.  However, very clear learning objectives must exist.  Assessment of these objectives and confirmation of their mastery must be part of the equation. Random comments and the teacher "shifting from group to group" may not be enough structure for the pre-schooler. Finally, fostering a love for learning and building self esteem through real accomplishment and mastery of a skill is sustainable learning.  Offering an "open ended question" or reflecting "I see you made a big red circle" may not be enough.

Currently our school in Bogota, Colombia is doing a project with learning with play. What we have observed is that children are enjoying school and learning. The bi
g question is what will happen to these children when they arrive to first grade and have to sit most of the day. Will they be turned off? Should primary focus in PBL and enquiry
earning?

My daughter is in 1st grade in a Brooklyn neighborhood public school. She has WAY too much homework, but her Pre-K experience at the school was great. She still thinks I'm the funniest person on the planet... except for her Pre-K teacher.

The demands on her were at times unrealistic, but my personal experience was that Brooklyn public school teachers can be exemplary.

Some parents and teachers have strong reactions about this topic, pro and con. It is time to start a conversation and the article made a very good point. In my experience, play is a very powerful way to engange little kids in the world of knowledge. It works!

The issue here is the amount of money flowing through the system even more than the sources.
An absolute limit on the amounts that could be spent by either candidates or parties would reduce the need to accept "bribes". This in turn would curtail PACs and other conduits for "soft"(dirty) money. Limits on single donations are not limits on free speech, but rather on corruption.
There is no perfect system for political donations, just as there is no perfect political system. The present state of American politics owes as much to the effects of bribery and lobbying as it does to ideology and that is where change is most urgently needed.

The federal government has balanced the budget, eliminated deficits for more than three years in just six periods since 1776, bringing in enough revenue to cover all of its spending during 1817-21, 1823-36, 1852-57, 1867-73, 1880-93, and 1920-30. We have also experienced six depressions. They began in 1819, 1837, 1857, 1873, 1893 and 1929.

History has shown that deficits are not only necessary (but not sufficient) for prosperity, but to avoid depressions.

Mann is right. Political strategy is the dominant force in today's political landscape, but it has little to do with moderate vs. extremist. The crux of our political issues is competent vs incompetent.

Democrats have worked themselves into an impossible position. They want to be the party of progress and a bright new future, but the entirety of their political capital and most of our budget is tied to ineffective anti-poverty entitlements and spendthrift for old white people. Democrats are straddling a barbed-wire fence. Clinton tried to move the party forward by pitching the Third Way and openly rebuking the "era of big government". It failed. So Democrats elected Obama, a drill-and-spend Democrat with a penchant for food stamps. He's been as thoroughly modern as LBJ.

In the 1980s, Republicans realized the impossible dilemma for Democrats, and they stole a march on entrenched interests by introducing new economic policy and expediting the rise of monetarism at the US Federal Reserve Bank. They called it "conservatism", which it certainly wasn't. Over time, Republicans became accustomed to riding the wave of deficit spending, and they grew lazy. Today, they just sit in right field and boo.

So much to fix. So little competence. The US must break ties with our old policies and programs and create something modern. Neither party is willing to sacrifice their political capital to make it happen, thus, independents are everywhere.

Now, at this stage in the game, yes a stronger GOP establishment that was more capable of reeling in the Tea Party would mean less polarization. But the GOP establishment created the Tea Party. The Tea Party is the establishment's attempts to manipulate working class people into backing an anti-working class economic agenda by recklessly stoking the fires of demographic angst and bizarrely anachronistic fears of communism and distrust of government. Those tools that they used to manipulate the Republican base eventually took on a life of their own, much like is now happening to Putin. They became trapped by the outrage they manufactured.

So, right now, yes, a stronger GOP establishment would reduce polarization, but maybe a weaker GOP establishment would never have been able to cook the whole problem up in the first place.

I would think that parties would be more useful, not less, under these circumstances.   A large number of engaged operatives would be just what is needed to dominate social networking, and that is what parties used to provide.  Instead of giving out free turkeys at Christmas, the precinct captains could send out emails and post to Facebook.

Parties have suffered many other blows in the past few decades than simply changes in financing. Most of those changes resulted from the expansion of electronic media of all kinds. Candidates rely more and more on direct approaches to voters through television, email, social networking, and the like, reducing the importance of party organizations. Even campaign organizations themselves are much more tied to individual candidates than to parties.

Parties obviously matter legislatively in both DC and the various states, but they matter less and less when it comes to electoral competition.

I believe that no parties would be a blessing.    Structure elections around individuals, paid for by the various governments, with those desiring to participate initially selected by petitions.    Then perhaps we could rid ourselves of the gang mentality politics we have now.

I agree that this is precisely the crux of our disagreement.  Art may and should confront, but in doing so the artist is not absolved of the moral consequences of their choice to create in a particular way.  For example, Tom Otterness shot a dog as part of a "conceptual" art project.  What he did he now regrets, but one reasonably might argue that the act of creation was morally repugnant.  And I dare say we can criticize Otterness both for results and for trying.  So, too, may we reasonably criticize the creators of DoK for "trying".  I have no qualm with artists dealing with issues of the day.  See the film "The Attack" for a smart, nuanced presentation of subtexts of the I/P conflict.  But this opera, in its conception, is exploitative of a murder victim, and consequently worthy of rebuke irrespective of how in isolation its "artistic merit" might be viewed.  I say all this as a lover of opera and as a subscriber to the Met.
Adding to Mark's words, by quoting Mayor Juliani at the time of 9/11 , this opera at the Met - and anywhere else - is a "Moral Equivalency" at its best.

Thank you Ms Grossman;  I have written Mr. Gelb with a plea to present this in HD at a time in the future. Perhaps it can be part of the summer HD series? Who knows?  But please let those of unable to go to NYC and witness one of the remaining performances have exposure.  When did we last have this sort of excitement and controversy for an opera?   Anthony Tomassini's review was a splendid reinforcement that this work is noble and  worthy of a broader viewership.

I was privileged to attend last night's performance of "The Death of Klinghoffer".  Given the vile and ignorant attacks on it, I would not have missed it for the world.   It is not a perfect work, but often moving and beautiful, and a necessary one to see and hear in these disjointed, cruel and violent times.  I commend everyone connected, who worked and performed under frightening circumstances.  Among the protesters, who keep being described as peaceful, were those who should be condemned, if not prosecuted, for language inciting violence.  I add my voice to those who are disturbed that this production will not be available to a wider audience than the people present at four performances.  It deserves to be available.  Whatever its faults, anti-semitism and the promotion of terrorism are not among them. If people refuse to believe that, it should not be because they are not able to make an informed decision.  The Met has an opportunity here to reach out to many more people who have more open minds.
